awd_titl_txt: Functional Dynamics and Energy Coupling Mechanisms of Mitochondrial Membrane Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
Mitochondria not only produce the vast majority of energy within eukaryotic cells, but also regulate cellular processes such as calcium homeostasis, lipid synthesis, and metabolite transport. The vital functions carried out by this organelle depend directly on the potential energy that is stored across its inner membrane in the form of a proton electrochemical gradient. Characteristic of all energy-conserving membranes, this potential is parsed as an electric field and a difference in proton activity across the lipid bilayer. This project will address two fundamental features of the mitochondrial inner membrane electrochemical potential. First, the changes in membrane protein structure that are driven by alterations in the energized state of the inner membrane will be investigated. Novel, high resolution fluorescence-based approaches will be employed to elucidate the manner in which alterations in the proton gradient and transmembrane electric field differentially change the conformation of a model mitochondria-resident protein. Elucidating the basis of such electromechanical coupling is vital to understanding how proteins in energy-conserving membranes harness the electrochemical potential to perform cellular work. Second, the energetic landscape of the topologically complex inner membrane will be investigated. Using precisely targeted pH-sensing and electrochromic probes to measure localized ion gradients and electric fields, the temporal and spatial heterogeneity of the inner membrane energetic profile will be measured with unprecedented resolution. By challenging the current dogma of electrochemical potential equilibrium across the membrane regions, this work is poised to create a new paradigm for understanding the energetic regulation of processes such as ATP production and local changes in the bilayer structure. These advances in the current understanding of membrane bioenergetics will be made possible by the technical innovations used in this research.

BROADER IMPACTS
This NSF-sponsored work will involve two teams of researchers in a model designed to promote multidisciplinary interactions and development of leadership in the sciences, emphasizing the involvement of students traditionally underrepresented in the STEM fields. The work will also serve to further develop and expand novel research tools in the construction of model membrane systems and in the process of site-specific polypeptide labeling, all of which will be made available to the scientific community. The education outreach component of this project is based on the Biology Summer Institute series in cooperation with the University of Connecticut Early College Experience Program. This series of modular classroom and laboratory courses offers professional development to teachers from regional high schools, exposing them to advances in research and current scientific topics, which can be integrated into their own curricula during the subsequent academic year. As this program develops, the Institute will be expanded to include summer courses for high school students as well. Taken together, this education outreach will be highly integrated with the research activities of the project. Moreover, the outcomes of this pedagogical outreach model will be disseminated in educational publications and conference workshops as a means of effectively helping to raise scientific literacy of the public.

por.por_cntn:
Mitochondria are the “power plants” of the cell because they produce the majority of chemical energy (ATP) that is required for cellular functions. Protein complexes of the oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) system in the mitochondrial inner membrane pump protons across the membrane, storing the potential energy as a proton gradient (termed an electrochemical proton potential) that can be parsed as a concentration component (a gradient of protons) and an electric potential. The protons then can flow energetically downhill to drive the machinery that makes ATP. The proper functioning of the OXPHOS system requires not only protein complexes, but also the proper lipids that make up the membrane bilayer, specifically signature phospholipid of the mitochondrion called cardiolipin. Knowing how such energy conserving membranes operate is key to understanding how mitochondria perform their myriad functions in the cell. The purpose of this NSF-sponsored research program was to address several open questions regarding the energy coupling mechanisms of the mitochondrial inner membrane.

The first goal of this research addressed how changes in the energized state of the inner membrane drive structural changes within key proteins that are embedded within the bilayer, so-called electromechanical coupling. Using the multicomponent protein import machinery as a model system, we used our developed advanced fluorescence spectroscopy techniques to understand how particular regions of channel proteins undergo conformational rearrangements in response to changes in transmembrane voltage and ion gradients. This work shed new light on our understanding of how the potential energy across the inner membrane can be harnessed to drive structural changes that are critical for molecular work; it also illustrated the structural plasticity of membrane proteins. The second goal of this research was to quantitatively evaluate the energetic landscape of the mitochondrial inner membrane. We undertook the development of electrochromic and pH-sensing probes on proteins targeted to specific regions of the inner membrane as a means to eventually measure spatial and temporal variations in electrochemical potential. We also evaluated the ionization and phase polymorphic properties of cardiolipin, which contributes to the surface charge of the inner membrane and therefore to its electrostatic potential profile. Hence, using our technical innovations, this work will render transformative advances in membrane bioenergetics. From a broader perspective, the results will also be relevant to aspects of cellular dynamics and regulation that are directly tied to the energized status of the inner membrane, including calcium homeostasis, lipid synthesis, apoptosis and protein trafficking. The third goal of this research was to elucidate the phospholipid dependence of OXPHOS complex activity using a host of novel model membrane systems. To this end, we have used advances in technology to reconstitute membrane proteins and complexes in nanoscale bilayers that are bound by belts of polypeptides or polymers. In this way, membrane assemblies like respiratory complexes can be isolated and used for solution-based experiments in a way that preserves their function and molecular environment. They can also be studied in the presence of experimentally defined lipids, or extracted from native cellular membranes to investigate the local lipid environment. Using this developed technology, we have addressed the role of cardiolipin in promoting the enzymatic activity of key respiratory complexes. We have also deduced the lipids that reside locally around particular proteins in the native membrane. Finally, we have shown how the peculiar phase behavior of cardiolipin is important for recruiting the redox protein cytochrome c to the bilayer. Taken together, these results give important insights into the role of protein-lipid interactions within the mitochondrion, and help elucidate how disorders in cardiolipin metabolism and biosynthesis can lead to human disease. The final goal of this research was to understand the structure-function relationships of the organelle-tethering ERMES complex. This work will give several new insights into the mechanisms by which the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondrion are tethered to facilitate interorganelle communication, and how this complex mediates the poorly understood process of lipid trafficking between the organelles. This research on the ERMES complex, common to human pathogens (Fungi, trypanosomes, Trichomonas, Acanthamoeba), has potential for development of therapeutic interventions for diseases such as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), fungal meningitis, histoplasmosis, and trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).
